headline.main: Cuisine a Weapon in Airlines' Passenger War

docs.abstract: Article on 'food war' to lure passengers; indus spends over $250-million a yr on food and drink; illus
docs.lead_paragraph: " This, you might say," sighed an airline executive as he surveyed a flight-kitchen table laden high with pastrami sandwiches, "is our year for the sandwich."
docs.snippet: " This, you might say," sighed an airline executive as he surveyed a flight-kitchen table laden high with pastrami sandwiches, "is our year for the sandwich."...

headline.main: Goodbye Stuffed Flounder, Hello Foie Gras

docs.abstract: Julia Reed travel article reviews restaurants in Seaside, Fla: Fish Out of Water, Basmati's Asian Cuisine, Cafe Thirty-A and Onano Neighborhood Cafe; photos; map (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I was growing up, we spent a few weeks every summer in Destin, Fla., in the heart of what is alternately known as the Emerald Coast and the Redneck Riviera. The state's tourism bureau prefers the first moniker to promote the powdery white sands and the clear blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico between Pensacola and Panama City. On the other hand, the Redneck Riviera (which also encompasses the Gulf Coast of Alabama) is the title of a country song by Tom T. Hall that includes the lyric ''Nobody cares if gramma's got a tattoo.'' My childhood was firmly rooted in the latter. We stayed in a motel called the Frangista Beach by an R.V. park whose denizens caught rays atop their Winnebagos and made hatbands out of Budweiser pop tops, which were in ample supply. When we weren't eating peanut butter and jelly or the crabs we caught ourselves at night, we dined in such ''nice'' restaurants as Captain Anderson's and the Sandflea, where the specialties were deep-fried shellfish and stuffed flounder. My parents bought whiskey at the Green Knight, which featured a giant green knight out front, and took us, on rainy days, to the Gulfarium in Fort Walton Beach.
docs.snippet: These days, the area known as the Redneck Riviera is a lot more riviera than redneck, especially when it comes to dining....

headline.main: Asian Cuisine as Diverse as Vancouver

docs.abstract: People with roots in India, China, Japan, England, France and, of course, the Pacific Northwest have long lived together in this famously diverse city. The result? A delicious intermingling of cuisine.
docs.lead_paragraph: From the outside, the Argo Cafe does not look like an Asian fusion restaurant - or really much of a restaurant at all. Situated ina light industrial section of Vancouver's Mount Pleasant neighborhood, it seems to date from another era. Cartoon versions of a white-capped chef and a pink-uniformed waitress decorate its cinderblock facade, and arced lettering promises "Hamburgers, Soup, Sandwiches, and more!"
docs.snippet: People with roots in India, China, Japan, England, France and, of course, the Pacific Northwest have long lived together in this famously diverse city. The result? A delicious intermingling of cuisine....

headline.main: Fusion Cuisine in a Bistro in Northport

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Soup du Jour Bistro in Northport, Long Island; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: DESPITE its name, Soup du Jour Bistro is about more than soup. It is not one of those soup-only spots springing up all over the Island, which offer a half-dozen or more choices with diners lined up for speedy takeout. The emphasis at this Northport newcomer is on bistro. It certainly looks the part. Diners are transported to Belle Epoque Paris. There is a marble bar, warm wainscotted wood walls, a pressed-tin ceiling and beveled-glass faux windows. Tables are topped with cloths covered with white bistro paper and adorned with fresh flowers and votive candles in satin-glass holders. Wood floors and tiny, old-fashioned tiles in the bar area complete the picture.

headline.main: It's Not Your Typical Mexican Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is fiesta time every night at Tequila Sunrise in Roslyn Heights. An exuberant mariachi band greets diners as they enter and later serenades at tableside, turning dinner into a joyful party. No one will confuse this charming upscale spot with the chain of casual Mexican storefronts found throughout Manhattan that, until recently, had the same name. The Roslyn Heights restaurant is one of five that started in Astoria. There is a second outpost in Queens, one in Larchmont and one in Florida.
